The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Andrew Wallace ) took the chair at 12:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
BUSINESS
Federation Chamber

The SPEAKER (12:01): I advise the House that the Deputy Speaker has fixed Wednesday 30 March 2022 at 10 am as the time for the next meeting of the Federation Chamber, unless an alternative day or hour is fixed.
PARLIAMENTARY REPRESENTATION
Member for Spence
Resignation

T
he SPEAKER (12:01): I inform the House that on the 22 February 2022 I received a letter from Nicholas David Champion resigning his seat as the member for the electoral division of Spence. With a general election pending, I have decided writs will not be issued and a by-election will not be held. This will avoid the necessity for the electors of Spence to participate in three elections within a short period of time.

Membership

The SPEAKER (12:02): I report to the House that on 11 March 2022 I received advice from the Chief Government Whip nominating members to be members of certain committees. In accordance with standing order 229(b), as the House was not expected to sit for several weeks, the appointments became effective on that date. I now call the minister to move a motion to resolve the membership of the committees.
Mr WOOD (La Trobe—Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs) (12:03): by leave—I move:
That members be appointed as members of certain committees in accordance with the list that has been placed on the table.
As the list is a lengthy one, I do not propose to read the list to the House. The details will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.
Question agreed to.
BUSINESS
Suspension of Standing Orders 31 and 33
Mr DUTTON (Dickson—Minister for Defence and Leader of the House) (12:03): I move:
That in relation to the presentation of, and reply by the Leader of the Opposition to, the 2022-2023 Budget that:
(1) standing order 31 (automatic adjournment of the House) and standing order 33 (limit on business) be suspended for the sitting on Tuesday, 29 March 2022; and

(2) standing order 31 (automatic adjournment of the House) be suspended for the sitting on Thursday, 31 March 2022 and at that sitting, after the Leader of the Opposition completes his reply to the Budget speech, the House automatically stand adjourned until 10 am on Monday, 11 April 2022, unless the Speaker or, in the event of the Speaker being unavailable, the Deputy Speaker, fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting.
Question agreed to.
BILLS
Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2021-2022
Third Reading

The SPEAKER (12:04): For the information of honourable members, at the last sitting of the House the House agreed to the third reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2021-2022. The House adjourned before the bill was read a third time. I now call the Clerk to read the bill a third time.
Bill read a third time.
Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2021-2022
Report from Federation Chamber
Bill returned from Federation Chamber without amendment; certified copy of bill presented.
Ordered that this bill be considered immediately.
Bill agreed to.
Third Reading
Mr WOOD (La Trobe—Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs) (12:05): by leave—I move:
That this bill be now read a third time.

I would like to thank all of the members who have contributed to the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2021-2022 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2021-2022. These additional estimates appropriation bills seek authority from the parliament on additional expenditure of money from the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the remainder of this financial year. Passage of the bills will ensure continuation of the government programs and the Commonwealth's ability to meet its obligations for 2021-22.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
CONDOLENCES
Kitching, Senator Kimberley Jane Elizabeth
Mr MORRISON (Cook—Prime Minister) (12:07): I refer to the death of Senator Kimberley Jane Elizabeth Kitching and I move:

That the House record its deep regret at the death, on 10 March 2022, of Senator Kimberley Jane Elizabeth Kitching, Senator for Victoria since 2016, place on record its appreciation of her long and meritorious public service, and tender its profound sympathy to her family in their bereavement.

We gather on this motion in sadness and in grief to mourn a life that ended mid-flight, at its prime—a life that I did not have the good fortune to know well, like many others in this place. But what I can say is that she confounded her critics from when she first arrived, and, in my own case, through the simple, everyday gentleness and kindness of her heart in our irregular exchanges.

Hers was a life that was brave and formidable, principled and strong. Kimberley was also kind and generous, joyful and full-hearted. Hers was a life enriched by language and literature, strengthened by her life's love and tempered by the struggles and sadnesses of her life. The scripture says of life that sometimes we may see through a glass dimly, and maybe that was the case with our understanding of Kimberley Kitching, because, in an instant, we knew what we had lost. In the suddenness of that moment, as we learned on that evening, we saw clearly the strong, principled parliamentarian who had been in our midst and who carried a heavy burden for the positions that she took.

In honouring Kimberley Kitching today, I do not intend to claim that she had more in common with those on this side of the chamber. She did not. That would not be true, because she was a deep and passionate believer in her own political party. But I can tell you that she found great respect and friendships across this chamber and on this side of the aisle. She was a fair, diligent, hardworking parliamentarian. In this parliament alone, Senator Kitching put on notice almost 12,000 questions, probing, testing, challenging, upholding the truest traditions and respect for the Westminster system.

Above all and most importantly, particularly in a place such as this, I believe Kimberley Kitching was a great Australian patriot. She was a voice for democracy and human rights, a voice for Australia's place and security in the Indo-Pacific and standing up for what that required, and a voice for a world order that favours freedom. Kimberley Kitching had a great sense of Australia's place in the world and the tectonic plates of history that are shifting even now. That understanding of Australia and the world grew out of her childhood, I believe.

Kimberley was born in the Brisbane suburb of St Lucia. But her childhood wasn't confined to Brisbane; it covered all corners of the globe. Kimberley spent time in many countries with her father, a travelling academic, and became fluent in French, Spanish and Italian. She was also proud of her German and Russian language skills. After returning to Australia, she studied arts and law at the University of Queensland. It was during that time that Kimberley found her two great loves. First, she joined the Australian Labor Party. Then, at a Young Labor trivia night, she met her soulmate, Andrew Landeryou. The two found themselves on the same team—and on a winning team—that night. Kimberley later said, with a laugh, 'He was as nastily competitive as I was!' Similarly, last week, Andrew said: 'I had been warned of her. She had certainly been warned about me.' For both, it became the partnership and love of a lifetime.

Possessing a powerful intellect, grounded in history, languages and literature, and instructed by her deep Catholic faith, Kimberley understood that the purpose of power is only truly found through service. That's what guided her as a lawyer, a Melbourne city councillor and a union official. Of her time as a councillor, she said:
Some might think that local government is the lowest form of government; I prefer to think of it as the nearest.

As a union official she discovered what she called 'the joy of winning small battles', yet never thinking they were small. She believed in our exceptionalism as a people and the genius of our democracy as she regarded passivity a sin, declaring in 2017:
When I came here, I vowed to myself I wouldn't be one of those. I wouldn't die wondering what might have been or what I could have done; I'd go for it.
And, indeed, she did.

In the depth of her being, Kimberley believed in freedom, liberal democracy and human dignity. Days before her death she wrote a piece on Ukraine entitled, 'Dictators not to be appeased'. She was strong to the last. Of her beliefs, she said:
… I am idealistic enough to believe that you support good and you oppose evil, even if it costs you, even if it hurts you.

Kimberley was a passionate advocate for all those who suffer at the hands of tyrannical regimes, abuses which she said make us all the poorer, all the worse. Kimberley would reach out to anyone in this pursuit. Her Senate colleague and friend James Paterson said, 'She would poke and prod and badger us all to do more for the Uighurs, the Hong Kongers, the Tibetans and other oppressed people around the world.'

Kimberley also helped form the Parliamentary Friends of Democracy, a cross-party group committed to safeguarding Australia's security and sovereignty. But perhaps her most notable and timely contribution was securing bipartisan support for the Magnitsky laws and allowing for targeted sanctions on human rights abusers and offenders. She was the champion of this in her own party. It is her achievement. For her efforts, Kimberley was awarded a Magnitsky Human Rights Award last year in London, reiterating to the audience her determination to confront the 'choking hands of authoritarian regimes'. To those who greased the wheels of autocrats, she said: 'No, we will not look away while you do wrong.' Rather,' she said, 'we will look them straight in the eye and say, "We shall make pariahs of you all."'

Sergei Magnitsky was the inspiration for the Magnitsky-style laws that my government passed last December. He was an attorney and auditor who exposed corruption and was ultimately detained, tortured and killed for his actions. Today, the government is listing 25 Russians for serious human rights abuses and 14 Russians for serious corruption, which ultimately led to the jailing, torture and death of Sergei Magnitsky. These individuals will be subject to targeted financial sanctions and travel bans. This aligns us with the actions of our partners, ensuring these perpetrators of egregious abuses and corruption find no safe haven in Australia. And this is the first of many such sanctions under our government's new Magnitsky-style laws. In doing so I can think of no greater fitting tribute to Kimberley Kitching than following through on her life's work.

Kimberley's friendships with coalition members and senators were real. They were heartfelt; they were genuine. And many a tear has been shed on this side. The member for Canning sent me a short video of his children, Jonathan and Beatrice, opening a Christmas present from Kimberley and Andrew. The present came with a big red bow, and it was children's books: Wreck this Picture Book, 12 Days of Christmas, Wise before Five, and The Mysteries of the Universe. And the card, read aloud: 'Jonathan and Beatrice, may you have the first of love and the gift of peace.' What a kind heart. James Paterson tells the story about the day his son, William, was born. And he'd only told his family but somehow Kimberley found out, and out of the blue she turned up at his office with presents for William, and later there was a dress for his daughter, Emily, and books too.

In addition to her husband, Andrew, and her parents, Leigh and Bill, I also want to extend my and Jenny's sympathies to Bill and Chloe. In the hours after her death, Bill, in his heartfelt grief, wondered aloud if she would have been better off never having gone into politics. Well, what I can say, Bill, is that our country is grateful that she did. Two centuries ago the poet William Wordsworth wrote Character of the Happy Warrior. He wrote of the happy warrior, saying: 'She finds comfort in herself and in her cause; and, while the mortal mist is gathering, draws her breath in confidence of heaven's applause. This is the happy warrior; this is she that every woman and man in arms should wish to be.'

So, on behalf of the government and this parliament, can I extend to Kimberley's husband, Andrew; her parents, Leigh and Bill; and her brother the gratitude and condolences of the people of Australia. We have lost a great Australian patriot. May God bless you and may Kimberley, our happy warrior, rest in peace.

Mr ALBANESE (Grayndler—Leader of the Opposition) (12:18): On behalf of all of us on this side of the House, I thank the Prime Minister for his heartfelt words. I also thank the Prime Minister for the conversation we had on the night of Kimberley's tragic passing, and also the Deputy Prime Minister for the discussion I had on that evening as well.

Even with the passage of more than a couple of weeks, the sense of shock at Senator Kimberley Kitching's death has not softened. It is hard to fathom that now when we speak about our friend and colleague we do so in the past tense. In this place we are used to celebrating the lives of those who served the Australian people: long lives; lives that blazed brightly through the spring and summer of existence long enough to be granted the sweetness of autumn and the reward of retirement and reflection; lives that ended in the fullness of time—but not today. Kimberley's fire has gone out tragically early. Fifty-two is no age for life to end. She gave so much in those 52 years, but she had so much ahead. When a life is curtailed so cruelly, the sense of all those years unlived lingers, entire decades that should have been theirs.

After a globetrotting childhood through a mosaic of countries, cultures, schools and languages, Kimberley's career was fittingly multifaceted. She was a Melbourne city councillor. She was a lawyer, a political adviser in the Bracks-Brumby state Labor governments in Victoria, and general manager of the Victorian No. 1 Branch of the Health Services Union. And then she arrived in the Senate with a bang, guided by her determination to make a difference for Australians.

Kimberley was passionate about the cause of Labor. She was passionate about international affairs, passionate about democracy and defending our way of life. One notable way that she channelled that energy was in her advocacy for a Magnitsky act in Australia to allow sanctions to be imposed on individuals connected to regimes guilty of violating human rights. She was a staunch defender of Israel and just as staunch a critic of China's treatment of Uighurs and Tibetans and other minority groups in China. Her compassion for human suffering was unwavering. Here's just some of what she had to say about Australia's friends in Afghanistan when their nation once again fell under the shadow of the Taliban—she was talking about those who assisted us:

These people risked their lives to assist us and work with us. It would be a national disgrace if we were to abandon them now to the terrifying revenge of their enemies. Even worse, it would be a failure on the part of the democratic countries if we were just to sidle off into the night.

I think one of the most significant moments in what was a remarkable and memorable send-off to this remarkable Australian at St Patrick's Cathedral in Melbourne was when stories were told by the member for Maribyrnong and others about Kimberley's efforts in getting people to safety as the Taliban returned in Kabul and Afghanistan. The fact that some of those whose lives Kimberley Kitching literally saved were present in the pews of St Patrick's Cathedral that day was something that will remain with everyone who attended Kimberley's service.

As a result of her concentration on these issues of international affairs and democracy and human rights, the ALP's national executive has determined, upon my recommendation and in consultation with Andrew and the family, to institute a Kimberley Kitching human rights award at each national conference for someone who's a member of the Australian Labor Party who follows Kimberley's legacy of being active in human rights and being an advocate often for those without a voice, and I think that is a fitting tribute to Kimberley going forward.

Her range was very broad as well. She recently brought her energy and drive to the Senate inquiry into Australia's sovereign capability in manufacturing. Just how crucial that is has been highlighted by the COVID pandemic, which has made it all too clear that, when the world is turned upside down, the most precarious place for Australia to be is at the end of the global supply chain. Kimberley understood the connection between national security and making things here. In that inquiry Kimberley helped bring many voices together in a bid to drive the case for improving Australian manufacturing.

On a personal level, I had the privilege of travelling with Kimberley on a delegation to Taiwan just a few years ago. Not surprisingly that was a delegation that included Brendan O'Connor and Michelle Rowland and Tony Zappia and Milton Dick. It was a terrific delegation in which we were talking one on one with the leadership of Taiwan about the importance of its position as a democratic nation. The truth is, as well, at that point, though, she was so strong an advocate—and she was strong. She was smart, she was vivacious and she was always the life of any room that she was in. The truth is we didn't always agree on every issue, but no-one expects that in something as broad as the Australian Labor Party. You never get the harmonies or the big chords if you're all singing the same note. But there was no denying Kimberley's energy, which is why I appointed Kimberley, after that visit, to the frontbench of the Labor Party, firstly as shadow assistant minister for government accountability and then as shadow assistant minister for government services and shadow minister for the National Disability Insurance scheme, where she worked so closely with her friend Bill Shorten, the member for Maribyrnong. She also served as Deputy Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate.

Politics can be difficult. There's so much at stake, passions are high and there isn't always automatic agreement as to which is the best course of action. People fight for what they believe in, and Kimberley was a great fighter for her beliefs. She had a big presence, powered by a sharp mind. She stood her ground. She had strong opinions, and she was a fighter in the best possible sense. Kimberley Kitching was a formidable force in her own right. There is now such a poignancy to Kimberley's own words when we lost our friend and colleague Senator Alex Gallacher last November. As she put it then:
The death of a colleague while they still serve here in the Senate is a reminder to all of us that our time on Earth is limited and that we should never waste a day, or indeed a minute, here.
Kimberley didn't waste a second. It's worth going back to her first speech in the Senate. She said this:

I come here to represent everyday Australian people: the working Australians, the families, the students, the hospital cleaners, the retail workers, the mortgage holders, the renters, the mums and dads, the 4 am shift workers, the nurses, the police, the firefighters and the factory workers.
She went on to say:

I come here to represent the people who work hard, pay their way, do the tough things, build our community and only ever ask in return that we remember them in this place and make their opportunity the focus of every decision we make in their name.

Kimberley's death has been really hard on the Labor family. We have lost one of our own. Her place in the Senate is empty today, but, for her many friends here, on both sides of the political divide, it will be hard to shake off that expectation that she might walk through the door at any moment.
My condolences go especially to her beloved husband, Andrew. In that speech to the Senate, Kimberley reflected on their marriage and said this:
We have lived an adventurous life together—that much is certain.

Well, may the glow of the adventure stay with Andrew always. My sincere condolences as well to Kimberley's parents; to her brother, Ben; and to all of her family and friends. May Kimberley rest in peace.

Mr JOYCE (New England—Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development and Leader of the Nationals) (12:28): To the parents—to Bill and Leigh—to Ben and obviously to Andrew: our hearts go out to you all, to lose a wife, a sister and a daughter. It is a terrible thing when parents have to preside over the death of one of their children.

From a hilltop, I always believe you can understand the view without having to travel to every corner of what you see. And, with Kimberley, of course, most of us only saw her from time to time. But it's amazing how a little piece of dye can change the colour of the water and how one person's life can have an effect on the course of a nation. What's more remarkable about this is that it wasn't done by a prime minister, or a deputy prime minister, or a minister, or a member of a government. A person's passion and conviction, from opposition, could not only affect the course of a nation but also be recognised globally. That is a remarkable thing. It's a remarkable thing because Kimberley was a remarkable person. She was a person who spoke five languages, including Latin. That's the mark of an exceptional talent. It's the mark of an exceptional brain. It's such a great attribute and a great quality and an incredible resource for this parliament, no matter which side you reside on. It's something that's respected.

There are very few people in our lives for whom we remember where we were when we heard of their passing. I know exactly where I was. I was near the barbecue at Matt and Linda's place in Armidale. A text came through on the WhatsApp for the Nats saying that Kimberley Kitching had passed away. I just remember the absolute shock. I didn't think I would feel shock about it. I didn't think that that was where I was. But I did. There was something there that just hit you in the heart straight away. I rang the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Maribyrnong. I asked: 'Is this true? Has this happened?'

Whether you're a Uighur, whether you're a Tibetan, whether you're an Afghan refugee, whether you're a tyrant, you had someone in Australia who was watching you and someone in Australia who made a difference. I also recollect, as was brought up by the Leader of the Opposition, hearing of someone's resourcefulness, cunning and guile. She was focused on getting people out of Afghanistan, keeping them alive. She had the passion to identify the individual and say: 'I've got enough energy to get you out. And after I get you out, I'm going to look for somebody else to get out.' When you think about it, how many of us in this chamber did that? She had the compassion and the focus to say: 'Today it's my job. I can do this. I can organise things. I can tell this person what to wear so that they can get to the place so that they can get evacuated. I can find the person in the Australian Defence Force and say, "Look out for this person; they're coming. And, when they arrive, make them safe."' All these things talk to the character of a person. It's the responsibility of all of us, from our position of safety in this incredible democracy, to look out for the people who are swimming with the sharks and to work out what we do.

Those attributes that she had included her faith—strong faith—and she was not embarrassed about it. So often in this place we think, 'I must have something, but there are views I have which I'll be quiet about.' She had a strong faith. She had a strong Catholic faith. She was a good Catholic. I'm not such a good Catholic, but she was a good Catholic. She was proud of it. She was proud of the Labor Party; she really was. In all of the discussions I've had, she was exceptionally proud of the Labor Party. She was a strong unionist; she really was. She was a strong unionist. She was a patriot. She had a patriotism that called others out—it called out China, when so many people couldn't mention it. That's strength. That's real strength. Our nation needs that.

She was a great senator. I've had the luck to be in both houses. I'm not going to say what is a bad senator, but a great senator is one who can get to the nub of the issue, who can be the inquisitor, who can make you uncomfortable, who does their research so that when you're sitting on the other side of the table you feel awkward because they've done their homework and they're ready for you. That is what makes a good senator. Having good senators means there is an inquiry and the government is held to account. That is what is supposed to happen. That is a great attribute.

Senator Kitching believed in our parliament and she believed in democracy. These are the attributes that are part of any good parliamentarian. This is such a loss. The Magnitsky laws—yes, we will always remember that—are just one part, though. As Vikki said, we should focus on the strength of the person and not be distracted by other issues. The strength of the person is what is to be remembered.

In closing, 52 years of age is when most of us start. This is such a loss to our nation. To Andrew, to Ben, to Bill and to Leigh: I know our nation has been affected. The parliament recognises and remembers what your daughter, your sister and your wife has done. These are not so much footsteps in the snow; these are elephant steps that people can follow and can see.
In Catholicism, we always say, 'May the saints and the angels welcome her into paradise.' May she rest in peace. Amen.

Mr SHORTEN (Maribyrnong) (12:36): The premature death of Senator Kimberley Kitching, struck down in her prime at just 52, with so much more to give, leaves a hole not just in our hearts but in Australian public life. I send my condolences to Kimberley's husband, Andrew. As I said elsewhere, we were in the blast zone of this immense and devastating loss, but Andrew is at ground zero. I send my condolences to Kimberley's parents, Bill and Leigh, and to her brother, Ben. I thank her Labor colleagues and her many colleagues across the aisle, both here and in the Senate, who have been so generous and gracious in the circumstances.

Senator Kimberley Kitching is just the fourth woman in the Australian parliament to die in office, and the youngest. We have moved condolences before in this place. I have spoken before on matters of great people, great Australians, but I've never before spoken on one about someone who was a personal friend of such proximity. It is still shocking to me and my wife, Chloe; we were there when she had just passed suddenly on the side of a road in Strathmore in the north-west of Melbourne. I appreciate that all of us here and all Australians have experienced the loss of dear friends and family members, so the shock is not unique and I do not claim it to be unique. But to be with her husband, consoling him, and to have my wife call the Anglican priest—the nearest priest we could find—to administer last rites, and to see her as a form covered by a shroud and a blanket in the middle of the road is confronting. None of those who serve here should ever be reduced to such a form—but of course, she is not; her legacy is real.

We heard the lovely condolence motion contributions of the Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister and will no doubt hear from my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. We know a lot of her achievements. Perhaps some were not aware of so many. We have lost a Latin speaker. We've lost a French speaker. You never know when that could be useful. She was charming. We lost someone who could somehow manage to get, in the cathedral of St Patrick's, the Minister for Defence and the secretary of the CFMEU in Victoria, two pews from each other. No photo exists, regrettably, of that.

I want to talk about an attribute of hers in this condolence, and it's courage. Courage in public life is admirable. I am sure and confident that her stand on human rights, on justice for the underdog, both here and abroad, writes another page in our party's proud history of universal rights and our championship of them. To that end, I want to, in particular, thank our leader, Anthony Albanese, for creating the Kimberley Kitching human rights award to honour her in coming years. This does bring comfort to her family. So it doesn't all go away, all that talent, all that light. We are connected, and Kimberley's influence lingers. It lingers because she was an example, I submit, of courage.

She believed in what the Irish poet Seamus Heaney called the republic of conscience. Some of us might visit this republic from time to time when it is personally and possibly convenient, but in my experience my friend Kimberley was a permanent resident of the republic of conscience. She came to the Senate not to merely serve time, not to merely occupy space. She regarded politics as a vocation. She believed in politics for purpose and power for purpose. Kimberley's view was: if there is a person without power, you give them the power of your advocacy, the sweat of your advocacy. She had a quiet, moral courage—the courage to speak up, perhaps, when it isn't always popular—to take the road less chosen; to pursue causes which may be unfashionable at the time; but she was never one to cut the cloth of her values to suit the fashion of the day.

She was courageous in the day-to-day things as well. At the end of January this year, she was down at Brimbank Park. She had a beloved dog, Nancy-Jane. A brown snake came out, as it does, along the river of the Maribyrnong, and intersected between her and Andrew, and her dog, Nancy-Jane. Nancy-Jane looked like she was going to plough across the path of the brown snake. As we know, brown snakes have a bad temper on them. I only found this out later, but Kimberley just set at the brown snake, to rescue the dog. I know that Nancy-Jane, if I'd been walking her, would have been on her own—with my fingers crossed! I know I'm the only one here who would have done that, though! Now, as Andrew poignantly recalled in his eulogy, Nancy-Jane will forever be waiting on the front step for Kimberley to come home.

I believed that Kimberley would be good, but I could never have guessed how remarkable she would become as a Labor senator. Her small office put in 12,000 questions on notice into the government this parliament. Not all have been answered. She scrutinised the government waste on the NBN. She was concerned about Putin and, as has been remarked, she was an advocate for Australia developing Magnitsky laws. The Muslim Uighurs benefited from her advocacy, as did the Tibetans, as did the democracy activists of Hong Kong and the people of Ukraine. And she certainly saw our debt still owing to the people of Afghanistan.

I mentioned at her funeral—but I briefly wish to reprise it for the record—what she did after 15 August last year when the Taliban captured and seized Kabul. On 22 August a young 17-year-old VCE student, Sam Daryabi from Cranbourne—himself remarkably enterprising—reached out to me on LinkedIn, as you do. It was about his brother's fiancee. The brother was in Melbourne. He'd arrived here in 2010 from Christmas Island. He now runs a successful plastering business. But the fiancee was stranded in Afghanistan. Her name was Roya. She was an ethnic Hazara. That's one of the groups being targeted and punished by the Taliban. Roya was outside the eastern gate of the Kabul airport, and we can all remember the images of the crowds crouched in the septic ditches. She wanted to flee, but, of course, it was difficult getting through the Taliban and the NATO forces. I knew that Kimberley had an extensive network of security and international contacts, so I turned to her, along with reaching out to the government and our own officers and the shadows. I made her aware of Roya's story. She leapt into action. She obtained a temporary visa for Roya. She got it to Sam, the younger brother, who emailed it to the sister-in-law outside the gate. There was another challenge, though, even though the paperwork was right: how do we get Roya through the cordon? She had a brainwave. She got Roya to photograph herself in a yellow scarf. Somehow that photo came to us, and somehow—I'm still not utterly clear how—Kimberley managed to get that photo from herself to a brave ADF private standing on the gate in Kabul. It is good how she could combine international intrigue, good works and a dose of fashion. Roya is safe. She has started her new life in Melbourne. She generously attended the funeral with others, and she wore that yellow scarf as a tribute.

She wasn't the only one she helped; there were 30 other Afghans. I'll include the names of some of them in the Hansard: Ahmad Zia Mayar, Hassan Hamidi, Khadija Azizi, Hasina Rahimy, Parisa Sekandari, Shazia Mohseni, Hamidullah Nadeem, Abdul Manan Momad, Hasina Dostyar, Mohammad Zaker Sadid, Ajmal Ramyar, Fahima Rahimi, Abdul Hakim Ramyar, Emal Ramyar, Zahra Karimi, Zohra Karimi. When you think about it, isn't it one of the great tests of politics: the things that you do which, if no-one else did them, wouldn't have happened? There's much that we do in this place which, to be honest, if we didn't do it, someone else might. Occasionally there come opportunities that, but for your contribution, but for what you individually bring to this place, wouldn't have happened. Thirty people, I have no doubt, but for her, would not be here. I visited Roya's family's house in Cranbourne. They're hardworking people. They will have family in successive generations. Long after, perhaps, the nice condolences here are forgotten, there will be families in Australia—good Australians of Afghan heritage—who, but for Kimberley Kitching, mightn't have had that chance.

A mighty Labor heart has definitely, sadly, beaten its last beat. Her legacy of courage is remarkable. There are going to be many firsts now without Kimberley. We will feel her absence in Senate estimates. For Kimberley, Senate estimates was like running out onto the MCG. She's gone home to Queensland. Next week she will be finally laid to rest in Brookfield. I did wonder, in the pain of those hours after her passing: perhaps it would've been better if she had never gone into politics. I want to make clear now that I don't agree with what I've said. I've changed my view completely upon reflection. I say to Kimberley, if she can hear us in some fashion: you lived every unforgiving minute with 60 seconds of distance running. Courage with no malice, courage with no jealousy, courage with no bitterness at all. Farewell, comrade. Farewell, dear friend. Rest in peace.

Mr DUTTON (Dickson—Minister for Defence and Leader of the House) (12:47): I want to follow the fine words of the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Prime Minister and the member for Maribyrnong. The passion, the depth of feeling, is obvious in their contributions. Bill, your experience, and that of Chloe's, was remarkable. You provided an exceptional speech at St Patrick's on the day of Kimberley's funeral.

I want to express my condolences to Bill, to Leigh, to Ben, to Andrew, to the entire Labor family, and, importantly, to Kimberley's staff. All of us in this place survive only because of the sacrifice and the contribution of our staff. Kimberley was no exception to that. They would feel acutely, no doubt, to this very day and for a long time into the future the loss of their beloved boss and somebody with whom they have worked very closely on many of these causes, including the repatriation and the safe passage of those in Kabul, as detailed earlier by the member for Maribyrnong.

We're here to mourn, and appropriately so, but we're also here to celebrate a wonderful life. I can affirm, as I'm sure many in this chamber can, that Kimberley loved expensive champagne. In my office we were able to drink expensive champagne, share some food and really talk about matters that were important to our country, leaving the partisanship aside and concentrating on the issues that she was passionate about and that I was passionate about. I was introduced to Kimberley by Mathias Cormann, our very dear mutual friend. When he left the Senate, he said, 'You must spend time with Kimberley.'

On a good day, I guess we could name most of the senators in the other place, but I had not met Kimberley before. I didn't know much of her apart from the fact, of course, that her two fluffy white cavoodles were named Ronnie and Nancy-Jane—and if she had that interest in the Reagans, then I presumed we had something in common that we might be able to share one day.

I enjoyed her company immensely. She was a person with a great warmth, a great heart, a great glow. She brought that into one-on-one meetings and meetings with her colleagues, with her constituents and with the many people that she was able to touch. She had sacrificed, in many ways, her own career by speaking out on issues that were important to her. She did put the interests of our country ahead of her own self-interest. She did talk on topics. She was frank in relation to human rights abuses and she was passionate about caring for people and making sure that the future of our country was on a steady path. For that, we certainly celebrate.

As Bill pointed out before, I knew something was on in St Patrick's Cathedral when I walked in and John Setka was just a row in front of me in the pews. I thought she had a great capability and a great capacity, but it was obvious to me that that was a truly eclectic gathering in the cathedral. It was a beautiful service, a wonderful ceremony and a wonderful celebration of her life. She had an incredible love of family, and that was demonstrated through the contributions, in particular, of her father during the course of the service. It's easy to see where her passion came from, where her intellect was first nurtured. She was able to express, I think, the love of her family, the love of her parents, in particular, and her dear brother, Ben, through her contribution in life.

She had a great love of our relationship with the United States and of AUKUS and of the alliance. She would have been there last night celebrating the great relationship with the United States, because she intellectually understood the need, more than ever, for that relationship to be reinforced. She wasn't afraid to express that.

I want to, in closing, acknowledge that the Senate have lost one of their best, and that our country has lost somebody who should have contributed for many decades into the future. But, as has been noted, she did pack a lot into her short life of 52 years. She was a great humanitarian. She was a great human being. She was a dear friend to many. The fact that she has brought us together as a parliament to celebrate her life in this chamber today, and in the other place, is a great testament to the qualities that she had on display unashamedly during the course of a great life. We honour her here today.

Mr MARLES (Corio—Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (12:52): Can I start by acknowledging and thanking the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and the Leader of the House for their kind words and the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Maribyrnong for theirs. In so doing, I also acknowledge the really fine speeches that were made at Kimberley's funeral by her husband, Andrew, by her father, Bill, and by the member for Maribyrnong. In another forum this morning, I noted that I have been watching the member for Maribyrnong make speeches over a very long period of time but none was finer than the one he made at the funeral—as he has here—to honour a person that he loved.

Kimberley Kitching came to the Senate with purpose. She had been around politics all her life, as a union official, as a staffer, as a lawyer, as a Melbourne city councillor. She understood the power of the Australian Senate, the privilege of being a member of this parliament and the opportunity of it all. From the very first moment that she was appointed to the Senate until that tragic day, which is still less than three weeks ago, she did not waste a second. Kimberley's policy passions, as people have stated, were national security, foreign policy and strategic policy—passions I share, so it won't surprise people to know that we spoke often about them. Kimberley had a very keen sense about where Australia's national interests lay; about how, as a nation, we needed to advance that; about what wasn't being done to pursue it. She was acutely aware of the historic nature of this moment in time—its threats, its challenges, its opportunities, but, above all, its deep complexity.

What's become really apparent in the last few weeks is the extent to which Kimberley touched people across this parliament, and the way in which she had friendships across the aisle—and those friendships were deeply sincere. But those friends will forgive me for a moment if I share an observation that the member for Maribyrnong made, which is that inside Kimberley beat a partisan Labor heart. Kimberley really believed that, when the nation faced difficult moments, as we do now; when the nation needed to demonstrate strength; when it needed to have intent and it needed to be thoughtful, then, just as with Fisher and Curtin, the true custodians of national security were Labor. Kimberley believed that to her core, as do I.

Kimberley was passionate about human rights—and here the story becomes a little more personal, because Kimberley and her husband, Andrew, had in their lives experienced pain and disappointment. They knew that in the darkest moments it can be pretty lonely. They were not the first to make that observation. But what was really unique about Kimberley was the way in which she lived her truth. There have been countless times in political life—and actually just in life in general—when I have watched somebody go through a crisis and standing next to them were Kimberley and Andrew. Here I speak from personal experience. I can only say how grateful I was that, in that moment, Kimberley and Andrew were there.

I think these personal qualities underpinned Kimberley's commitment to human rights, because, when she saw persecution and injustice and the pain that that caused people, she was moved and so she acted, using her voice. Be it for Myanmar, Tibet or the plight of the Uighurs, she was a fierce advocate. But she was also moved by crises on a global scale, as has been noted numerous times today. I remember talking to her in the aftermath of the fall of Kabul, and I genuinely was amazed that she had been working 24/7 to help people a long way from here find a pathway to safety—as the member for Maribyrnong has told us, 30 of them.

The Magnitsky award which she received at the end of last year was specifically a recognition of Kimberley's championing of Magnitsky legislation through this parliament. But I would like to think that, at least in terms of the way we see this, it was recognition of Kimberley in a broader context. Previous winners of a Magnitsky award include Senator John McCain and Alexei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader. As a 2021 recipient of a Magnitsky award, Kimberley is in august company.

But to simply focus on Kimberley as a politician is rather to miss the point. Kimberley was warm. She was fun. So many people have remarked in the last few weeks that she was excellent company. She was all that but a whole lot more. She was thoughtful and she was sensitive. Many years ago now, when my wife, Rachel, and I were getting married, we knew we really wanted to be married; we just couldn't get our heads around the idea of actually having a wedding. So we took the coward's route and we ran away and got married in Cairns. On the way to the airport, rather than sending invitation cards to our friends, we went to the post box and delivered a whole lot of apology cards to our friends that we were getting married and that there would be no wedding reception. On our return, not surprisingly, this hadn't gone down so well with our friendship group and so a number of friends, Kimberley chief among them, organised a ridiculous event, a mock wedding, which was actually at the member for Maribyrnong's house one Saturday afternoon. As silly as that event was, we all had a wonderful time. But, much more importantly for Rachel and me, we were deeply moved.

On a lighter note, more recently, Kimberley returned from a trip to Afghanistan and she rang me and said that she'd got me a present and she wanted to come over and give it to me. It was a cup. It was a coffee cup that I think she had bought from a Starbucks cafe, which must've been on the military base at the airport. Kimberley and I both loved travel, so she knew that I would like a cup which came from such an exotic place as Kabul. She knew that I would be amused by the way American fast food chains managed to get themselves into every corner of the globe, including a war zone. But the cup didn't say 'Starbucks'. It said 'Star Wars Kabul'. It had on it a face of a stormtrooper with some bullet holes in it. She knew I was a devotee of Star Wars. It's hard to imagine a cup more calculated to tickle my fancy than this one. When she came to my office, she was literally giggling with excitement as I opened it. Of course, the point of that story is that she knew all that; she knew all of that about me. When she saw that cup, she knew I needed to have it, and she wanted to be the one who gave it to me.

A world in which there are not these Kimberley moments—well, it's just a world which is a lot less special. But none of that compares to the pain which is being experienced right now by Kimberley's family—her mother, Leigh; her father, Bill; her brother, Ben; but most particularly her husband, Andrew, who I've actually known a fair bit longer. I can't think of a couple in my life who have been more of a team in every single thing they've done. We tend to say their names together as much as we say them separately. At the funeral there was the beautiful reading from Kahlil Gibran, his observations about the relationship between joy and sorrow:
Your joy is your sorrow unmasked.
… they are inseparable.

It is a profound thought. I do know that in the unspeakable pain which Andrew is feeling right now—as I've spoken to him on a number of occasions since Kimberley's passing—it is completely obvious to me that he has a deep gratitude for having had the joy of Kimberley in his life, and that gratitude for Kimberley, pure and everlasting, all of us should share.
Mr SHORTEN (Maribyrnong) (13:02): by leave—I table the names of the people that Kimberley helped.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Rob Mitchell ): As a mark of respect to the memory of Senator Kimberley Jane Elizabeth Kitching, I ask all present to rise in their places.

span.span: Honourable members having stood in their places—

p.span: The DEPUTY SPEAKER: I thank the House.
Debate adjourned.
Reference to Federation Chamber
Mr WOOD (La Trobe—Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs) (13:03): by leave—I move:
That the resumption of the debate on the Prime Minister's motion of condolence in connection with the death of Senator Kimberley Jane Elizabeth Kitching be referred to the Federation Chamber.
Question agreed to.
BILLS
Supply Bill (No. 1) 2022-2023
First Reading
Message from the Governor-General recommending an appropriation for the bill announced.
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mrs Marino.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mrs MARINO (Forrest—Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Territories) (13:04): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Supply Bill (No. 1) 2022-2023 together with Supply Bill (No. 2) 2022-2023 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 1) 2022-2023 seek appropriations to facilitate the continuation of normal government business for the first five months of 2022-23. Supply Bill (No. 1) 2022-2023 provides for just over $80 billion of appropriations for proposed expenditure on the ordinary annual services of the government.

The appropriations proposed in this bill are generally based on five-twelfths of the estimated 2022-23 annual appropriations. The 2022-23 estimates are broadly the 2021-22 base, adjusted for economic- and program-specific parameters and the effect of decisions announced as part of the 2021-22 Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook or included in the 2021-22 additional estimates appropriations bills. The five-twelfths allocations are adjusted where necessary for programs or entities that have uneven expenditure early in the financial year—for example, administered payments under programs that are made up-front in the financial year.

The bill also includes COVID-19 response measures that have been extended since the 2021-22 Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook or the additional estimates processes. This ensures that funding is available over winter and that essential support can continue to be provided in the 2022-23 financial year.

I wish to emphasise that this bill seeks only to fund government expenditure on an interim basis until the 2022-23 budget appropriation bills have passed. Therefore, no new measures for the 2022-23 budget are included in this bill. This arrangement allows for an annual appropriation bill for the ordinary annual services of government to be passed by the next parliament in the usual way.

The bill also contains an advance to the finance minister, or AFM, provision of $2.4 billion to provide the government with the capacity to allocate additional appropriations for urgent and unforeseen expenditure; $2 billion of the AFM provision is set aside for COVID-19 related expenditure and $400 million for other urgent and unforeseen expenditure.

While the COVID-19 AFM provision of a higher value accommodates the ongoing response to pressures emerging from the pandemic, the general AFM provision of a lower value marks a return to standard AFM arrangements. This completes the government's commitment to return to pre-COVID AFM settings when circumstances allow. The COVID-19 related AFM remains a temporary measure and will be ceased in a future year when it has been determined that COVID-19 risks have sufficiently moderated.

In light of the size of the AFM, it is proposed to continue the strong accountability and transparency arrangements that have been in place from 2019-20 through to 2021-22, including a regular media release in weeks when AFMs are issued which reports and reconciles the use of the AFM provision and seeking the concurrence of the opposition for any proposed AFM greater than $1 billion.

Details of the proposed expenditure are set out in the schedule to the bill, the explanatory memorandum and the portfolio budget statements tabled in relation to the 2022-23 budget appropriation bills.

The bill must be passed in this session to ensure that funding is available for the first months of next financial year to all entities from 1 July 2022, thereby ensuring the continuity of program and service delivery.
I commend this bill to the chamber.
Debate adjourned.
Leave granted for second reading debate to resume at a later hour this day.
Supply Bill (No. 2) 2022-2023
First Reading
Message from the Governor-General transmitting particulars of proposed expenditure and recommending appropriation announced.
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mrs Marino.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mrs MARINO (Forrest—Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Territories) (13:10): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Supply Bill (No. 2) 2022-2023, along with Supply Bill (No. 1) 2022-2023 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 1) 2022-2023, seeks appropriations to facilitate the continuation of normal government business. Supply Bill (No. 2) 2022-2023 provides for just under $10.7 billion of appropriations that are for purposes that include capital works and services, payments to states, territories and local governments, and equity injections for the first five months of 2022-23.

The appropriations proposed in this bill are broadly based on five-twelfths of the estimated 2022-23 annual appropriation. The 2022-23 estimates are largely the 2021-22 base adjusted for economic and program-specific parameters and the effect of decisions announced as part of the 2021-22 Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook or included in the 2021-22 additional estimates appropriation bills.

The five-twelfths allocations are adjusted where necessary for programs or entities that have uneven expenditure early in the financial year—for example, the Government Schools National Support Program in order to provide additional transition support for the Northern Territory government schools to implement reforms agreed under the Commonwealth government's Quality Schools package. The supply bills also include COVID-19 response measures that have been extended since the 2021-22 Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook or the 2021-22 additional estimates processes. This ensures that funding is available over winter and that essential support can continue to be provided early in the 2022-23 financial year.

The bill also establishes the debit limits for 2022-23 for general purpose financial assistance payments and national partnership payments. The debit limits in the bill reflect the full year of the estimated 2022-23 debit limits so that agreements with other governments can be established with certainty for the full year. The bill must be passed in this session to ensure that funding is available for the first months of next financial year to all entities from 1 July 2022, thereby ensuring the continuity of program and service delivery.

As with Supply Bill (No. 1) 2022-2023, this bill seeks only to fund government expenditure on an interim basis until budget appropriation bills have passed. Therefore, no new measures for the 2022-23 budget are included in this bill. This arrangement allows for annual appropriations to be passed by the next parliament in the usual way.

The bill also contains an advance to the Minister for Finance, a provision of $3.6 billion to provide the government with the capacity to allocate additional appropriations for urgent and unforeseen expenditure: $3 billion of the AFM provision is set aside for COVID related expenditure and $600 million for other urgent and unforeseen expenditure. While the COVID-19 AFM provision of a higher value accommodates the ongoing response to pressures emerging from the pandemic, the general AFM provision of a lower value marks a return to standard AFM arrangements. This completes the government's commitment to return to pre-COVID-19 AFM settings when circumstances allow. The COVID-19 related AFM remains a temporary measure and will be ceased in a future year when it has been determined that COVID-19 risks have been sufficiently moderated.

In light of the size of the AFM, it is proposed to continue the strong accountability and transparency arrangements that have been in place from 2019-20 through to 2021-22, as outlined in the speech for Supply Bill (No. 1) and as particularised in the explanatory memoranda to the supply bills. Details of the proposed expenditure are set out in the schedules to the bill, the explanatory memorandum and the portfolio budget statements tabled in relation to the 2022-23 budget appropriations bills. I commend this bill to the chamber.
Debate adjourned.
Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 1) 2022-2023
First Reading
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation for the bill announced.
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mrs Marino.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mrs MARINO (Forrest—Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Territories) (13:16): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 1) 2022-2023 provides appropriations for the first five months of 2022-23 for the operations of the Department of the Senate, the Department of the House of Representatives, the Department of Parliamentary Services and the Parliamentary Budget Office. This bill seeks approval for appropriations from the Consolidated Revenue Fund of just under $114 million. The appropriations proposed in this bill are based on five-twelfths of the estimated 2022-23 annual appropriations. The 2022-23 estimates are broadly the 2021-22 base, adjusted for economic and program specific parameters.

The bill must be passed in this session to ensure funding is available to the parliamentary departments from 1 July 2022, thereby ensuring the continuity of the parliament's operations. As with the other supply bills, I wish to emphasise that this bill seeks only to appropriate money to fund government expenditure on an interim basis until the budget appropriation bills have passed. Therefore, no new measures for the 2022-23 budget are included in this bill. This arrangement allows for annual appropriation bills for the latter part of next financial year to be passed under the new parliament in the usual way. Details of the proposed expenditure are set out in the schedule to the bill, the explanatory memorandum and the portfolio budget statements tabled in relation to the 2022-23 budget appropriations bills. I commend this bill to the chamber.
Debate adjourned.
Supply Bill (No. 1) 2022-2023
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Mr THISTLETHWAITE (Kingsford Smith) (13:19): Labor support the passage of these supply bills. We don't block supply. We believe that the ordinary course of government should be funded by the government and the opposition in this place. Supply Bill (No. 1) 2022-2022 and the other supply bills have been introduced given that we're so close to an election. Normally they would be introduced after the appropriation bills. But Labor agrees that, given the proximity to the federal election and given the appropriation bills won't be passed in the usual time line, the supply bills are required to ensure the continuity of government into the 2022-23 financial year. These bills generally provide for around five months of funding for the 2022-23 financial year, and budget estimates will be indexed for parameter changes and adjusted for any terminating measures.

A moment ago we saw one of the ministers introduce, for the third reading, the 2021-22 appropriation bills. One would expect that that would have been done last year, with the 2021-22 budget. But the reason it wasn't was that the government forgot to bring the bills back to the parliament. When you talk about being all about announcement and not about follow-up, look no further than what they've done in the parliament today. They announced the appropriation bills associated with the last budget, but they forgot to bring them back to the parliament to give them effect—no follow-up whatsoever.

This government is all about announcement and not about follow-up, in a number of areas. We've seen it over the course of this government—firstly, with the bushfires in 2019 and the disastrous effects they had on communities throughout the country. Once again, announcements were made in the wake of those. Do you think they've followed up with any of it? Have any of those communities received the funding they were promised by the government in the wake of those bushfires? We've still got people living in caravans and tents who haven't had their homes rebuilt because of that—all about announcement, never about follow-up.

We're seeing it again at the moment with respect to the floods, with rain once again bucketing down on communities in the north of New South Wales and in southern Queensland. If you were a government that was serious about climate change and, instead of trying to use it as a political weapon, your approach was that this is an existential threat, that it's a problem that we, as a parliament and as a government, have to work to solve with the Australian people, then you'd be prepared for what's going on in the communities of South-East Queensland and northern New South Wales, and, indeed, in Western Sydney. You would have made sure that you had in place, and you worked with those communities on, measures to protect them, through mitigation infrastructure, through the construction of facilities to ensure that people could be housed—evacuation centres and the like—when they lose their homes and all of their belongings. But, no. The government seek to use climate change as a political weapon. As a result, they're not prepared. They are all about the announcement, nothing about the follow-up.

The Emergency Response Fund was their announcement, in the wake of what had occurred in the bushfires and in the flooding that we saw in 2017, to protect those communities. In the Emergency Response Fund, there was $4.7 billion put aside by this government. How many projects has this government delivered out of that fund to protect communities in bushfire zones and flood zones and cyclone zones? A doughnut—not one. they are all about the announcement, never about the follow-up. It's Australian communities and individuals that are suffering.

If you were a government that took climate change seriously and you were interested in solving the problem, you would have used some of that money in the Emergency Response Fund to build levees, to build culverts, to build evacuation centres, to look to protect communities, to have household resilience programs put in place, as the Queensland government has done, so that people can retrofit their homes to protect themselves from the risk of cyclone damage or bushfire damage or flood damage. But, no: the government seek to politicise and use climate change as a political weapon to serve their political purposes, purely for what goes on here and not what goes on in the wider community. And that is the reason why the Prime Minister of Australia cannot even walk down the street in Lismore, in Mullumbimby, in Ballina—in communities affected by flooding—and talk to the Australian people. He knows, his ministers know and his MPs in those areas know that he would have copped a shellacking from the Australian people and the members of those communities for his lack of response to the danger and threat that severe weather has posed to those communities and for his lacklustre response in supporting those communities and getting in place emergency measures to provide them with support. Then, to make matters worse, they used politics by providing emergency disaster based support funding only for Liberal or National Party based electorates, rather than for Labor based electorates.

Is it any wonder the bloke can't walk down the street and any wonder that members of the National Party and the Liberal Party have spoken out so strongly against the Prime Minister? One of them has resigned from the New South Wales parliament in disgust at the approach of this Prime Minister and his support for Australians and their communities in the wake of the flooding that occurred in the north of New South Wales and South-East Queensland. It's all about announcement and never about follow-up, and that's what we're going to see with this budget tonight: another budget that'll be about saving the bacon of marginal seat MPs on that side of the chamber—pork-barrelling to save their bacon in a looming election—rather than what is in the best interests of our nation.

Our economy has been struggling for some years and Australians know it. They've been saddled with cost-of-living pressures for the last decade under this government. Why? Because their real wages haven't been increasing. Their real incomes have been falling under this government. They've been burdened with cost-of-living pressures associated with child-care, housing and insurance costs, and now petrol costs are skyrocketing and rents are starting to take off once again. Yet, at the same time, their wages haven't been increasing. In fact, they've been going the opposite way. Real wages in this country have been falling. Why? Because this government supports policies like cutting penalty rates for some of the lowest paid workers in this country, those who work shift work and on weekends.

This government supports employers being allowed to bring in labour hire contractors to undercut wages and conditions for workers who are performing full-time work for particular businesses. This government has done nothing to stop the explosion of insecure work in this country. It sees people working two and three jobs just to pay the rent, to make ends meet. It has led to a crisis in our aged-care system.

The royal commission titled its report into what's going on in aged care in this country Neglect. If you ever want an indictment of a government, look no further than a royal commission that says 'neglect' about the aged-care system. That is exactly what this government has done when it comes to aged care. The royal commissioner pointed out that Australians aren't getting the level of care they deserve, in certain circumstances. You have people who are overworked and underpaid, who are working two and three jobs just to make ends meet, and the quality of care has suffered.

Do you think this government will deal with that issue in the budget tonight? Of course they will not. They will not do anything that ensures they will even remotely come close to lifting the real wages of Australian workers in this country. They don't support Australian workers. They never have. They put in place laws that diminish their wages and conditions and ensure that over a decade you get no real wages growth in this economy for Australian people. That's this government's philosophical bent and that's the way they always do things. They attack superannuation. They attack wages and conditions. They make sure that employers have the wherewithal to cancel enterprise agreements when they can't get agreements with their workforces.

As a result, we have one of the lowest levels of enterprise bargaining and agreement-making in this country's history. Labour productivity in this country has been falling under this government. The amount of income that we earn as a nation per hour worked has been falling, and that is an indictment on this government's economic management.

Will you see in the budget tonight any productivity-enhancing measures? No, you will not. You'll not see any commitment to ensuring that women get access to the workforce by cheaper child care, which you will see under Labor policy. You will not see any commitment to ensuring that workers are paid fairly when they're working beside someone who's doing the exact same job, on the exact same terms and conditions, but is a permanent employee and not employed by a labour hire company. You will not see anything that this government will do to improve labour productivity, nor will you see anything done to increase business investment that's been falling or housing affordability. These are the issues that are affecting Australians and you will not see them dealt with by this budget tonight.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Llew O'Brien ): The debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 43. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate resumes.
STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
Domestic and Family Violence

Mr PERRETT (Moreton) (13:30): 'He used his access to the children to terrorise here, refusing to bring them back at the time they had agreed to. He stole his middle daughter's comfort toy and refused to give it back. Aaliyah cried and cried when forced to see him.' That is part of the report from the coronial inquest in the murders of Hannah Clarke and her three beautiful children, Aaliyah, Laianah, and Trey. They were murdered 770 days ago by the person who was supposed to love them the most; 765 days ago I stood up in this chamber and called on Prime Minister Morrison to act to prevent further horrific acts of family violence. I called on the Prime Minister to repeal section 61DA of the Family Law Act, the 'Presumption of equal shared parental responsibility when making parenting orders'. Frontline domestic violence workers have been calling for this change over many years. Even a bipartisan parliamentary report, with a Liberal Party majority, recommended it way back in 2017.

This small change would save lives. It would shift the culture and practice towards a greater focus on safety and risk to children. I introduced my private member's bill 653 days ago to make this legislative change. There has been support from across the chamber for my bill. Sadly, we know that there are other Hannahs living in terror and other children who are being put in dangerous situations today. Hannah had no power over the monster who stole her life and her children's. The Prime Minister does have power to change the law; he could bring on my private member's bill this week. He could do it today. I'm sure the member for Griffith, who is closely connected with the family, would agree.
Bennelong Electorate: Liberal Party Preselection

Mr ALEXANDER (Bennelong) (13:31): Last week I was delighted to see the Liberal Party in Bennelong conduct a full and open preselection meeting to decide who will be the candidate to represent Bennelong at the upcoming election. I announced my retirement last November to provide plenty of notice to would-be candidates and to the party to steward a full and fair contest free of potential distractions and impositions.

It was great that 250 preselectors turned up at the meeting. It's a courageous act to put one's hand up for consideration at a preselection meeting. It is a stressful process. I commend and thank the nominees who stepped forward: Rose Torossian, Trenton Brown, Craig Chung, Gisele Kapterian and Simon Kennedy. Rose is a wonderful local Liberal Party member and activist over many years. Trenton is a passionate and effective local councillor on Ryde council. Craig is a proud former local councillor and an active community advocate. Gisele has incredibly impressive professional experience and a compelling personal backstory. But there can only be one winner, so I congratulate Simon Kennedy on gaining Liberal Party preselection for Bennelong. The family man won the night on the back of his outstanding performance, outreach to the selectors, impressive professional achievements and local connections. He grew up in Bennelong and was captain of Epping Boys High School. I commend him to the people of Bennelong. He will make a fine representative, and he has my full endorsement and encouragement. (Time expired)
Petition: Cystic Fibrosis
Dr FREELANDER (Macarthur) (13:33): For the second time in this parliament, I am tabling a petition in this chamber regarding treatment for Australians with cystic fibrosis.

span.span: The petition read as follows—

p.span: The PBAC have now officially recommended Trikafta, but people with CF cannot access this critical medication until it is listed on the PBS. We can't wait any longer to access this life changing medication. Every day without Trikafta means increasing lung damage for those who need this vital medicine. For some of us in the CF Community, our lives cannot truly start without Trikafta. Trikafta is a crucial medicine for the CF Community, with lifesaving implications for around 90% of Australians living with cystic fibrosis.

We therefore ask the House to Expedite the listing of Trikafta on the PBS urgently. The House must quickly work with Vertex and the PBAC to make sure onboarding data, price ratios and other hurdles do not delay access to this lifesaving medicine. We must get Trikafta to the people now. We are so close and have waited so long. We cannot wait any longer. Trikafta must be on the PBS before the election. Trikafta has been recommended, now please get it listed today.
from 58,274 citizens (Petition No. EN3915)
Petition received.

Dr FREELANDER: First of all, I would like to thank the previous CEO of Cystic Fibrosis Australia, Nettie Burke, the present CEO, Jo Armstrong, and the cystic fibrosis community for putting this petition forward for the second time. This is something that almost 60,000 Australians have signed. It regards the use of Trikafta, which is a remarkable treatment for the most common variant of cystic fibrosis with abnormalities in the delta F508 gene. This has caused a life-saving treatment to be available for over 2,000 Australians with cystic fibrosis. We've seen people who were on the heart and lung transplant list taken off because of the use of Trikafta. The minister has only just approved this after some delay and after rejection by the PBAC over 12 months ago. It has recently been approved. It's now available and will save the lives of over 2,000 Australians. This is a wonderful new treatment that has revolutionised the treatment of cystic fibrosis in Australia.
headspace

Dr ALLEN (Higgins) (13:35): In my first speech I spoke about my cousin Matthew. I was very close to Matthew. He had a beautiful but troubled soul. Back in the 1990s there were very few mental health services and even fewer that were youth oriented. Sadly, Matthew died by suicide at the age of 25. For my aunty and uncle there are no words to describe their grief.

Those experiences have actually been at the back of my mind as we faced the COVID pandemic. Mums and dads in Higgins have told me about anxiety and depression levels that are through the roof in young children as they've faced the uncertainties COVID has brought. As a paediatrician and now the member for Higgins, I've always been a strong advocate for greater mental health services, especially for our youth.

That's why I'm so proud that, as I come to the end of my first term, we can announce that a new headspace in Higgins has just opened its doors. This means the youth of Higgins will have greater access to clinical mental health professionals, to judgement-free physical and sexual health advice from onsite GPs and to alcohol and drug counsellors. These services will help our youth balance the juggle of studying and jobseeking as they emerge from the lockdowns into a post-COVID world. So please, if you need support, don't hesitate to reach out to headspace, because your mental health is as important as your physical health.
Morrison Government

Ms THWAITES (Jagajaga) (13:36): The past few years have shown us that when the going gets tough we can rely on this Prime Minister not being there—on this government and this Prime Minister failing to take responsibility and to do their jobs. Whether it's failing to take action on climate change, failing to get us vaccines when we need them, failing to keep older Australians in aged care safe or failing to make sure that wages are keeping up with the cost of living, at every stage this Prime Minister and this government have failed to do their job. Today's budget seems to be more of the same: a short-term political fix focused on Scott Morrison's future but not the future of our country.

My community is tired of it. They did their part through all these difficult years of the pandemic. They deserve a government and a Prime Minister that will do their part and that are prepared to take responsibility and do their jobs. They deserve a Labor government that believes climate change is real and will take action on climate change. They deserve cheaper child care to make it easier for families to juggle work and caring. They deserve a government that gets that we need to protect and strengthen Medicare and that we should all be able to see a doctor when we need to. They deserve a government that will fix and protect the NDIS instead of leaving families lying awake at night worrying about their children's future. They deserve a genuine national anticorruption commission. They deserve a Labor government.
Menzies Electorate: Stronger Communities Program

Mr ANDREWS (Menzies) (13:38): I was delighted recently to be able to support a number of community groups in my electorate of Menzies to obtain grants under the Stronger Communities Program: the clubroom fit-out of furniture and kitchen equipment for the Macedon Blues soccer club; CCTV camera equipment for the Templestowe RSL; a defibrillator, ride-on mower and gardening equipment for the Doncaster Bowling Club; car park resurfacing at the Manningham Tende Beck Scout Group; two commercial fridges for the Templestowe Football Club; gardening equipment for the Doncaster Community Gardens; an electronic scoreboard for St Davids Cricket Club, an oval that's used by many other sports as well; an air conditioner for the Wonga Park Country Fire Authority; the purchase of equipment for the Eltham Sea Scouts; the construction of a shelter over a seated area for the Whitefriars Football Club; an electronic community noticeboard for fire warnings—something very important—for the Kangaroo Ground Country Fire Authority; tables and chairs for the Kangaroo Ground War Memorial Park; a grant to the Nillumbik Shire Council; another grant to the Nillumbik Shire Council for the upgrade of public bathroom amenities at Research Park; and carpeting for the op shop at the Rotary Club of Manningham. These are all very worthwhile projects undertaken by very important and vibrant community groups in Menzies.
Palmer, Mr Clive

Mr GORMAN (Perth) (13:39): On 27 February this year, it was reported that Mr Clive Palmer had purchased a Mercedes-Benz 770 Grosser Offener Tourenwagen used by Adolf Hitler. This was purchased from an unnamed Russian billionaire. On 28 February, I wrote to the Minister for Home Affairs to ask that she take action under the Customs Act to prevent this import and use all legal avenues available to the Commonwealth to prevent it. The minister released a statement saying: 'No-one gets a special deal, and the rules apply to all. Mr Palmer will have to comply fully with our import, customs and sanctions laws.' Mr Palmer and his spokesperson have refused to say if he has attempted this purchase, is still working on this purchase, or if this purchase was by any of his companies. And then, on 4 March, Mr Palmer threatened legal action against the Minister for Home Affairs, which makes so interesting the letter I received in response from the Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs on 11 March. The assistant minister wrote that he could not comment due to privacy reasons: 'I cannot comment on individual transactions or importations to Australia.' Curious. No action. No comments. He said I should report it to a website. I had written to the minister, and the response I got back was, 'Report it to a website.' This is the Scott Morrison 'not my job' approach that is throughout this entire government. This government should either act or legislate to stop Mr Palmer. I seek leave to table the correspondence.
Leave granted.
Reid, Mr Rex 'Harry'

Mrs ARCHER (Bass) (13:41): On Tuesday 15 February 2022, Rex 'Harry' Reid passed away in his 102nd year. He was a World War II veteran. I had the privilege of meeting Harry when I presented him with a commemorative medallion, for his service during the war, at the Launceston RSL in 2020.
